Product: Checking or savings account
Checking or savings account
Issue: Problem with a lender or other company charging your account
Sub-issue: Money was taken from your account on the wrong day or for the wrong amount
Consumer complaint narrative:
I sent information regarding a fraudulent deduction of {$5200.00} from my checking account after a deposit was made. I have contacted NFCU and have not received the exact information I requested. My family is undergoing challenging circumstances at this time because XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. So we need all the money we can save for her care. Unfortunately, at this critical time, I am having money transacted without appropriate controls and protections. The employees I have contacted have been extremely unresponsive and unprofessional. I am requesting a thorough investigation of the credit unions internal processes. There is absolutely no protection for vulnerable citizens like me. 

Subject : Immediate Action Required Regarding Check Deposit Rejection and Member Rights Dear [ NFCU Customer Service Manager ], I am writing to express my profound dissatisfaction and serious concern regarding the mishandling of a check deposit I made in XXXX, which has only now resulted in a deduction of {$5200.00} from my account. This deduction was made without prior positive confirmation from NFCU, leaving me unable to investigate or trace the source of the issue with the originating bank. 

As a loyal NFCU member for over 25 years and a veteran of this great nation, I expect the utmost care and diligence in handling matters related to my account. I was alarmed to learn that the rejection of the deposit and subsequent deduction were communicated to me months after the deposit was made, a failure that reflects a significant breach of trust and fiduciary duty on NFCUs part. 

Furthermore, the lack of professionalism and empathy I encountered when seeking clarity from both an agent and a supervisor during my recent call is unacceptable. At no point did they show any concern for the gravity of the situation, nor was there any effort to escalate the matter so I could understand why I am just being notified today. 

Beyond my rights as a client, I am fully aware of my rights under federal banking regulations, including the right to timely notifications regarding deposits and withdrawals, as outlined in the Truth in Savings Act and other relevant federal statutes. The failure to notify me in a timely manner not only undermines my ability to protect my financial interests but also may constitute a violation of these regulations.

I request the following immediate actions from NFCU : 1. A full and transparent explanation for the delay in notifying me of the rejected deposit, including why the originating bank refused the check and why NFCU did not provide earlier notice. 
2. A detailed investigation into how this failure occurred, including a review of NFCUs internal processes and staff conduct in handling this issue.

3. Corrective actions and safeguards to ensure that such an egregious lapse in communication and customer service never occurs again. 

As a veteran who has dedicated XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to protecting the freedoms and rights of this country, I find it deeply troubling that NFCU, an institution I have trusted for so long, has failed to protect my financial security with the same level of care. I expect a response from a senior manager, outlining the steps NFCU will take to rectify this situation and restore my confidence in your institution. 

Please be aware that I am considering further actions, should this issue not be resolved to my satisfaction, including filing a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) to ensure that my rights, as protected by federal law, are upheld. 

I look forward to a prompt response and a resolution to this matter. I trust NFCU will take this issue seriously and demonstrate the respect and attention owed to a long-standing member and veteran. Just saying that I am not the primary owner, and that my wife should have received an e-massage is simply heartless and morally wrong. XXXX should attempt to just walk XXXX steps and not even a mile in my shoes. 

Sincerely, XXXX and XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative: i am writing to follow up on my previous dispute regarding inaccurate and fraudulent information appearing on my credit report. The recent investigation results I received, were incomplete and unsatisfactory. The accounts in question remain inaccurately reported or were incorrectly verified despite the documentation I provided. Below is a detailed summary of the disputed accounts, legal citations, and the actions I am demanding to ensure compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : XXXX. XXXX XXXX  ( Account # XXXX ) Dispute : The account is incorrectly reported as charged off despite my dispute. I was coerced into a pay to delete arrangement, which XXXX XXXX failed to honor. I never provided written consent for this account to appear on my credit report. Legal Violations : 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : XXXX XXXX, as the furnisher of credit information, is obligated to conduct a reasonable investigation into disputed information. Since XXXX XXXX  has not provided valid proof of the charge-off or consent to report, they are in violation of this section. 15 U.S.C. 1681i : I demand reinvestigation of this account. The investigation failed to verify the charge-off based on valid documentation, which violates my rights under this section. 15 U.S.C. 1681c : If the charge-off was inaccurately reported or based on false consent, it must be deleted under this section. Adverse information can not be reported without proper verification. Action Requested : I request immediate deletion of the XXXX XXXX  account from my credit report as per FCRA Sections 1681s-2 ( b ) and 1681i. Please provide verifiable proof of the accounts accuracy or remove the account entirely. I also request a detailed description of how the investigation was conducted. XXXX. XXXX ( Account # XXXX ) Dispute : The original X1 account was deleted, but it reappeared under the name XXXX. This account is fraudulent and the result of identity theft. I have provided documentation of identity theft, including an FTC Identity Theft Report, yet this account remains on my credit file. Legal Violations : 15 U.S.C. 605B : Under this section, I submitted an identity theft report, which obligates the credit reporting agency to block and delete fraudulent information from my credit file. The continued presence of XXXX violates this provision. 15 U.S.C. 1681m : The agency has failed to remove fraudulent information related to identity theft, even after a valid dispute and report were filed. Action Requested : I demand the immediate removal of the XXXX account from my credit report. Under 15 U.S.C. 605B, this account must be blocked or deleted as it is the result of identity theft. Please provide proof of the steps taken in the investigation, as required under the FCRA. 3. Inquiries : Dispute : There are several unauthorized credit inquiries, including XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ), which are linked to identity theft and fraudulent accounts. Legal Violations : 15 U.S.C. 1681b : These inquiries were made without my authorization or permissible purpose. I have not granted consent for these inquiries to appear on my credit report. 15 U.S.C. 1681i and 605B : I demand these inquiries be removed immediately as they are the result of identity theft, and I have submitted the required identity theft documentation. Action Requested : I request that these inquiries be deleted from my credit report immediately. If these inquiries were authorized, please provide proof of my written consent or permissible purpose. Summary of Actions Demanded : Removal of the XXXX XXXX  ( Account # XXXX ) charge-off under 15 U.S.C. 1681i and 1681s-2 ( b ) unless verifiable proof of the charge-off can be provided. Deletion of the XXXX ( Account # XXXX ) under 15 U.S.C. 605B as a result of identity theft. Deletion of all unauthorized credit inquiries under 15 U.S.C. 1681b, 1681i, and 605B unless permissible purpose or written consent can be provided. An updated credit report reflecting these changes. A detailed report of how the reinvestigation was conducted, including copies of any documentation relied upon by the furnisher or TransUnion. Please conduct a reinvestigation of the disputed items within the 30-day timeframe as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act. If the information can not be verified or if the appropriate documentation is not provided, I demand the immediate deletion or correction of the disputed items. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I expect to receive a response within 30 days, including an updated credit report reflecting these corrections. Failure to respond appropriately will result in further action, including filing additional complaints with the CFPB, and I will seek legal remedies if necessary. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Debt collection
Consumer complaint narrative:
RE : Cease and Desist Demand Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to formally request that you cease and desist all collection activities regarding the above-referenced account. Pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( c ) As, there is a negative impact on my credit score for the amount of {$200.00} as of XX/XX/year>. I am exercising my right to request that you stop all communication with me regarding this alleged debt. 

Please be advised that I dispute the validity of the debt you claim I owe. I am requesting no further contact, whether by telephone, mail, or any other form of communication, including calls to my place of employment, home, or to third parties. Any further contact from your agency may result in a complaint being filed with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and/or my states attorney generals office for violation of the FDCPA. 

Please take notice that I demand the following : 1. Immediate cessation of all communications regarding the collection of the alleged debt.

2. That you inform all third parties or affiliates working on this matter of my request for the cessation of all communications. 

This notice is effective upon your receipt of this letter. I request written confirmation that you have complied with my request within 30 days of the date of this letter. 

Failure to comply with this cease-and-desist request will leave me no choice but to pursue legal action to protect my rights. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing in response to the recent findings communicated by Equifax regarding my complaint submitted. While I appreciate their investigation, I must strongly disagree with the conclusions drawn and reiterate that several inaccuracies remain unresolved on my credit report. Legal Basis for Disputing Inaccuracies Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681i, I have the right to dispute inaccurate or incomplete information on my credit report. Additionally, 15 U.S.C. 1681b restricts the sharing of my information without my consent. As such, I expect these rights to be upheld in accordance with federal law. Further, relevant Ohio Revised Code ( ORC ) provisions include : ORC 1345.01 - Ohio Consumer Sales Practices Act : This law prohibits unfair or deceptive acts in connection with the sale of goods or services. The reporting of inaccurate information on my credit report can be considered an unfair trade practice. ORC 1345.02 - Unfair or Deceptive Acts or Practices : The Ohio Attorney General has the authority to enforce this provision, which also protects consumers from false representations that may affect their creditworthiness. Disputed Items XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : The account continues to show as charged off with a balance due I am unaware of. I demand immediate correction under FCRA 611 ( a ), which requires that inaccurate information be corrected or deleted upon investigation. in this specific case this item should be deleted. XXXX XXXX : Although Equifax states this item is not currently reporting, I assert that the negative information associated with this account has not been removed as promised under the alleged " pay to delete '' agreement, violating FCRA 607. XXXX XXXX : Equifax indicates this account is not currently reporting, but it remains visible on other credit reports under different names like XXXX etc. I dispute its validity and request verification of this account 's reporting. XXXX XXXX XXXX : I dispute this collection account as I maintain that I never provided consent for this to be reported. Under FCRA 611 ( a ), I request proof of the debt and its legitimacy. Inquiries : The inquiries from XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX are unauthorized and result from identity theft. Under FCRA 605B, I demand their immediate removal. Ohio Department of Human Services : A new entry has appeared on my credit report related to this agency. I request immediate clarification regarding this entry and its legitimacy. Department of EducationXXXX XXXX : New accounts reported from the Department of Education and XXXX are disputed. I assert that I did not consent to their inclusion on my credit report. Verification is required under FCRA 609. Request for Action Given the ongoing inaccuracies and the significant impact they have on my credit profile, I request that the CFPB facilitate a more thorough investigation into these matters to have them deleted. I urge the CFPB to ensure my rights under the FCRA and Ohio Revised Code are upheld, requiring that all inaccuracies be corrected or deleted. I am prepared to escalate this matter to legal proceedings if necessary, as the failure to resolve these inaccuracies has been causing significant harm to my credit profile, impacting my ability to secure housing and necessary services. Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response regarding my request for further assistance.

On XX/XX/year>, I visit XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  branch for paying an utility bill. Then, I proceed to request to the teller, if I would be able to emit a payment to XXXX ( Electricity Company ), for the complete amount for my XXXX  chequing / savings account, and if I would not have problems with the payment, because in my XXXX XXXX XXXX an app for sending money instantly ) was displaying I did had full amount for doing that payment, from an receiving funds transaction. 

She replied that I would be able and would not have problems to emit the payment, but she did not verified, if in effect, funds where received by the usage of XXXX XXXX ( an " instant '' payment app. 

After that, the next working day ( XX/XX/year> ), I did observe a OD fee. 

As soon as the same day, I did call the bank, the reply me, I have to wait until transaction post. 

After, that transaction posted, from Customer Care, they request, I should visit or call XXXX XXXX XXXX to investigate that issue. From the branch, a customer service and sales representative told me to try to solve with Customer Care ( XXXX ). 

On XX/XX/year> I request an investigation in XXXX. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX  investigation, established, I should assume responsibility of the overdraft. Indeed, that letter was left by postman 14 days after, the letter was dated. 

I am against this charge, since always I configure a debit transaction ( ACH ) by myself, I always verify if I have enough funds or if funds where received. Why the branch teller did not tell me, I did not had enough funds to cover, the payment? And how their systems would allow to emit a payment from an account with NSF? If the teller would tell me, I would gladly deposit some money to cover that transaction. 

On the other hand, XXXX XXXX  shall express, that they as institution, would not process that day, after x hour, XXXX XXXX incoming funds. They have different frame time, would turn confusing to customer, especially, for those who are accustomed with Financial Institution, that would reflect instantly any incoming / outcoming XXXX XXXX transaction.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: Subject : Request for Validation of Debt XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX I am writing in response to an alleged debt associated with account number XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX I am requesting validation of this debt as per my rights under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 USC 1692g. I dispute the validity of this debt and am immediately requesting that you provide the following information : 1. The original contract binding me to this so-called debt. 2. The PAYMENT HISTORY with the original creditor and balance. 3. Copy of PROOF OF DEBT ASSIGNMENT. 4. Proof that I legally owe this debt to YOUR agency. 5. Proof that you are licensed and able to collect on this debt in my state. 6. The original XXXXURCHASE AGREEMENT. A. THIS IS NOT ANY DEBT THAT I ORIGINATED MYSELF. I HAVE NO IDEA WHERE THIS DEBT ORIGINATED FROM. This inaccurate information needs to be re-investigated immediately by both the Credit reporting agencies and the furnishers of this information that is appearing on my consumer report. NOTE : As you can see within the screenshots that I have attached, XXXX removed this account 45 days ago. Please complete this file. Pursuant to 15 USC 1681e ( b ), A credit reporting agency must maintain accurate records at all times within the files of consumers. Pursuant to 15 USC 1681i, please perform an internal re-investigation on the validity of this account in question that is showing up on your consumer report under my name and notify me of your results within 30 days of your receipt of this letter and update my credit report accordingly to your findings. If you are unable to provide proof of my requests, then the erroneous information MUST be DELETED within 30 days of your receipt of this letter from my credit report as this erroneous account is very misleading and not mine. This account is causing me great mental anguish and I am unable to obtain a mortgage at this present time due to this inaccurate information on my credit report. Debt Collectors and Debt Buyers must furnish 100 % accurate information on consumers at all times. 15 USC 168s-2 Responsibilities of Furnishers of Information to Consumer Reporting Agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION ( 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors a person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. Please note that until the validity of this debt is verified, I demand that you CEASE all collection activities and CEASE REPORTING TO CREDIT BUREAUS IMMEDIATELY until complete and verified. Also, it is the duties of credit reporting agencies to uphold their grave responsibilities to supply 100 % accurate information ONLY on all consumer credit reports as the banking system itself hinges on accurate information. DELETE THIS ERRONEOUS INFORMATION from ALL credit bureaus immediately if the information can not be verified/validated. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative: As of XXXX of XXXX, my student loans, around {$69000.00}, were transferred from XXXX to XXXX but my credit report has not been updated to show that I no longer owe XXXX. The student loans are being reported twice on my credit report showing open student loan balances with both XXXX and XXXX, which is negatively impacting my debt-to-income ratio, three credit scores, and my overall report. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am a victim of identity theft. I recently learned that my personal information was used to open an account. I did not open or authorize this account at XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and I therefore request that it be closed immediately. I also request that they absolve me of all charges on the account, and that you take all appropriate steps to remove information about this account from my credit files. 
Enclosed is a copy of my Identity Theft Report supporting my position, and a copy of my credit report showing the fraudulent items related to your company that are the result of identity theft. Also enclosed is a copy of the FTC Notice to Furnishers of Information, which details your responsibilities as an information furnisher to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ). As a furnisher, upon receipt of a consumers written request that encloses an Identity Theft Report, you are required to cease furnishing the information resulting from identity theft to any CRA.

The Notice also specifies your responsibilities when you receive notice from a CRA, under section 605B of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, that information you provided to the CRA may be the result of identity theft. Those responsibilities include ceasing to provide the inaccurate information to any CRAs and ensuring that you do not attempt to sell or transfer the fraudulent debts to another party for collection. 
Please investigate this matter, close the account and absolve me of all charges, take the steps required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and send me a letter explaining your findings and actions. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Account applications made on paper, online, or by telephone Account statements or invoices Records of payment or charge slips Delivery addresses associated with the account Records of phone numbers used to activate or access the account Signatures on applications and accounts Investigators report Please send me a letter explaining what you have done to : Inform XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, debt is the result of identity theft Stop collection proceedings against me Stop reporting information about the debt to credit reporting companies Provide me with the records I request Thank you for your cooperation. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX All furnishers of consumer reports must comply with all applicable regulations, including regulations promulgated after this notice was rst prescribed in 2004. Information about applicable regulations currently in e ect can be found at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau 's website, consumer nance.gov/learnmore. 
NOTICE TO FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION : OBLIGATIONS OF FURNISHERS UNDER THE FCRA The federal Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681-1681y, imposes responsibilities on all persons who furnish information to consumer reporting agencies ( CRAs ). These responsibilities are found in Section 623 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2. State law may impose additional requirements on furnishers. All furnishers of information to CRAs should become familiar with the applicable laws and may want to consult with their counsel to ensure that they are in compliance. The text of the FCRA is set forth in full at the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection 's website at consumer nance.gov/learnmore. A list of the sections of the FCRA cross-referenced to the U.S. Code is at the end of this document.

Section 623 imposes the following dut
ies : Accuracy Guidelines The banking and credit union regulators and the CFPB will promulgate guidelines and regulations dealing with the accuracy of information provided to CRAs by furnishers. The regulations and guidelines issued by the CFPB will be available at consumer nance.gov/learnmore when they are issued. Section 623 ( e ).

General Prohibition on Reporting Inaccurate Information The FCRA prohibits information furnishers from providing information to a CRA that they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. However, the furnisher is not subject to this general prohibition if it clearly and conspicuously speci es an address to which consumers may write to notify the furnisher that certain information is inaccurate. Sections 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) and ( a ) ( 1 ) ( C ).

Duty to Correct and Update Information If at any time a person who regularly and in the ordinary course of business furnishes information to one or more CRAs determines that the information provided is not complete or accurate, the furnisher must promptly provide complete and accurate information to the CRA. In addition, the furnisher must notify all CRAs that received the information of any corrections, and must thereafter report only the complete and accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 2 ).

Duties After Notice of Dispute from Consumer If a consumer noti es a furnisher, at an address speci ed by the furnisher for such notices, that speci c information is inaccurate, and the information is, in fact, inaccurate, the furnisher must thereafter report the correct information to CRAs. Section 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ).

If a consumer noti es a furnisher that the consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of any information reported by the furnisher, the furnisher may not subsequently report that information to a CRA without providing notice of the dispute. Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ).

The federal banking and credit union regulators and the CFPB will issue regulations that will identify when an information furnisher must investigate a dispute made directly to the furnisher by a consumer. Once these regulations are issued, furnishers must comply with them and complete an investigation within 30 days ( or 45 days, if the consumer later provides relevant additional information ) unless the dispute is frivolous or irrelevant or comes from a credit repair organization. The CFPB regulations will be available at consumer nance.gov. Section 623 ( a ) ( 8 ).

Duties After Notice of Dispute from Consumer Reporting Agency If a CRA noti es a furnisher that a consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of information provided by the furnisher, the furnisher has a duty to follow certain procedures. The furnisher must : Conduct an investigation and review all relevant information provided by the CRA, including information given to the CRA by the consumer. Sections 623 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( A ) and ( b ) ( 1 ) ( B ). 
Report the results to the CRA that referred the dispute, and, if the investigation establishes that the information was, in fact, incomplete or inaccurate, report the results to all CRAs to which the furnisher provided the information that compile and maintain les on a nationwide basis. Sections 623 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( C ) and ( b ) ( 1 ) ( D ).

Complete the above steps within 30 days from the date the CRA receives the dispute ( or 45 days, if the consumer later provides relevant additional information to the CRA ). Section 623 ( b ) ( 2 ).

Promptly modify or delete the information, or block its reporting. Section 623 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( E ).

Duty to Report Voluntary Closing of Credit Accounts If a consumer voluntarily closes a credit account, any person who regularly and in the ordinary course of business furnishes information to one or more CRAs must report this fact when it provides information to CRAs for the time period in which the account was closed. Section 623 ( a ) ( 4 ). 
Duty to Report Dates of Delinquencies If a furnisher reports information concerning a delinquent account placed for collection, charged to pro t or loss, or subject to any similar action, the furnisher must, within 90 days after reporting the information, provide the CRA with the month and the year of the commencement of the delinquency that immediately preceded the action, so that the agency will know how long to keep the information in the consumer 's le. Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ).

Any person, such as a debt collector, that has acquired or is responsible for collecting delinquent accounts and that reports information to CRAs may comply with the requirements of Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( until there is a consumer dispute ) by reporting the same delinquency date previously reported by the creditor. If the creditor did not report this date, they may comply with the FCRA by establishing reasonable procedures to obtain and report delinquency dates, or, if a delinquency date can not be reasonably obtained, by following reasonable procedures to ensure that the date reported precedes the date when the account was placed for collection, charged to pro t or loss, or subjected to any similar action. Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ).

Duties of Financial Institutions When Reporting Negative Information Financial institutions that furnish information to nationwide consumer reporting agencies, as de ned in Section 603 ( p ), must notify consumers in writing if they may furnish or have furnished negative information to a CRA. Section 623 ( a ) ( 7 ). The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has prescribed model disclosures, 12 CFR Part 1022, App. B. Duties When Furnishing Medical Information A furnisher whose primary business is providing medical services, products, or devices ( and such furnisher 's agents or assignees ) is a medica
l information furnisher for the purposes of the FCRA and must notify all CRAs to which it reports of this fact. Section 623 ( a ) ( 9 ). This notice will enable CRAs to comply with their duties under Section 604 ( g ) when reporting medical information.

Duties when ID Theft Occurs All furnishers must have in place reasonable procedures to respond to noti cations from CRAs that information furnished is the result of identity theft, and to prevent refurnishing the information in the future. A furnisher may not furnish information that a consumer has identi ed as resulting from identity theft unless the furnisher subsequently knows or is informed by the consumer that the information is correct. Section 623 ( a ) ( 6 ). If a furnisher learns that it has furnished inaccurate information due to identity theft, it must notify each consumer reporting agency of the correct information and must thereafter report only complete and accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 2 ). When any furnisher of information is noti ed pursuant to the procedures set forth in Section 605B that a debt has resulted from identity
theft, the furnisher may not sell, transfer, or place for collection the debt except in certain limited circumstances. Section 615 ( f ).

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau website, consumer nance.gov/learnmore, has more information about the FCRA. Citations for FCRA sections in the U.S. Code, 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. : Section 603 Section 604 Section 605 Section 605A Section 605B Section 606 Section 607 Section 608 Section 609 Section 610 Section 611 Section 612 Section 613 Section 614 15 U.S.C. 1681 15 U.S.C. 1681a 15 U.S.C. 1681b 15 U.S.C. 1681c 15 U.S.C. 1681c-1 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 15 U.S.C. 1681d 15 U.S.C. 1681e 15 U.S.C. 1681f 15 U.S.C. 1681g 15 U.S.C. 1681h 15 U.S
.C. 1681i 15 U.S.C. 1681j 15 U.S.C. 1681k 15 U.S.C. 1681l Section 615 Section 616 Section 617 Section 618 Section 619 Section 620 Section 621 Section 622 Section 623 Section 624 Section 625 Section 626 Section 627 Section 628 Section 629

Consumer complaint narrative:
RE Account Numbers XXXX XXXX, This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting my nonpublic and personal information without my written consent. Please show me the proof you sent me giving me options on how I could opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and proof showing you gave me the option to not disclose my transaction history each month with a third party.

The law states a consumer must give written consent to opt out of sharing their nonpublic information to the financial institution. I did this and you stated I did not have that right to opt out. It is a violation to report my transactions or experiences between you and I with a third party or consumer reporting agency without my written consent. It is the policy stated by Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers to insure the security and confidentiality of their customer records and information. This includes protecting against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information which could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to any customer.

I the consumer should have been given the opportunity, before such information was to be reported which gives me the option to direct you that such information should not be reported. I also should have been explained how I could exercise that nondisclosure option, which I was never advised. I have written multiple times, and you have continued to ignore my written request.

Your failure to comply with the law and my written request has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Again, I am requesting to opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and for you to remove all my transaction history from all nonaffiliated third parties such as Experian, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX immediately. Otherwise, I will pursue legal actions for every month my nonpublic information has been reported which could be a fine of {$1000.00} per violation. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX, BENEFICIARY Without Recourse, All Rights Reserved

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  **Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) ** XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX **Experian Information Solutions , Inc.** XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX **Subject : Formal Complaint and Notice of Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) ** To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint and to provide notice of violation concerning my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) due to the actions taken by Experian regarding my credit report.

**Details of the Complaint : ** 1. **Dispute Closure** : On [ XXXX, XXXX ], I submitted a dispute regarding certain inaccuracies found in my credit report. On XXXX ], I received notice from Experian that my dispute was closed, and the information was verified as correct.

2. **Subsequent Modifications** : However, I have recently observed that numerous modifications have been made to the disputed information in my credit report since it was closed. These modifications appear to be an attempt by Experian to contest its previous verification and to evade responsibility for the resulting harm and negligence that I have suffered due to the inaccuracies in my report.

3. **Investigative Requirements** : During this investigation, I stipulate that any continuing investigation into these items must include the disclosure of wet signatures and contracts associated with the accounts in question. If these documents can not be provided, I request that the account be removed from my credit report entirely as mandated by applicable regulations.

4. **FCRA Violations** : The actions taken by Experian constitute violations of the FCRA, specifically in relation to the accuracy of information reported and the obligations surrounding the dispute process. The FCRA mandates that credit reporting agencies maintain accurate records, and the changes made following the closure of my dispute suggest a failure to uphold that standard.

5. **FDCPA Violations** : Additionally, these actions may also reflect violations of the FDCPA, as they may be construed as unfair practices that impact my personal and financial well-being. I believe that the modifications made in an attempt to mitigate liability for your previous negligence exhibit behavior contradictory to the ethical standards mandated by the FDCPA.

**Resolution Requested** : I request that Experian : - Immediately cease all modifications to my credit report that have been made post-dispute closure.

- Provide me with a comprehensive explanation for the alterations made to my credit report while noting the basis for their legitimacy.

- Conduct a thorough investigation that includes the disclosure of wet signatures and contracts associated with the accounts in question ; if these can not be provided, the account should be removed from my credit report.

- Provide correction of the inaccurate information, ensuring full compliance with both the FCRA and FDCPA.

- Compensate me for any damages incurred due to these violations.

Please treat this complaint with urgency and the seriousness it warrants. I expect acknowledgment of this letter within 15 days and a detailed response regarding the actions that will be taken to rectify this situation. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response. 

Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX ]

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
RE Account Numbers XXXXXXXX XXXX This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting my nonpublic and personal information without my written consent. Please show me the proof you sent me giving me options on how I could opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and proof showing you gave me the option to not disclose my transaction history each month with a third party. 
The law states a consumer must give written consent to opt out of sharing their nonpublic information to the financial institution. I did this and you stated I did not have that right to opt out. It is a violation to report my transactions or experiences between you and I with a third party or consumer reporting agency without my written consent. It is the policy stated by Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers to insure the security and confidentiality of their customer records and information. This includes protecting against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information which could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to any customer. 

I the consumer should have been given the opportunity, before such information was to be reported which gives me the option to direct you that such information should not be reported. I also should have been explained how I could exercise that nondisclosure option, which I was never advised. I have written multiple times, and you have continued to ignore my written request. 

Your failure to comply with the law and my written request has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Again, I am requesting to opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and for you to remove all my transaction history from all nonaffiliated third parties such as Experian, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX immediately. Otherwise, I will pursue legal actions for every month my nonpublic information has been reported which could be a fine of {$1000.00} per violation. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Upon recent review of reports furnished by XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, I noticed an unfamiliar third-party MIDLAND CREDIT MANGEMENT I have no business association with, in possession of my private non-public financial information without my consent. 
On XX/XX/2024 a Certified CEASE & DESIST notice XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was delivered to MIDLAND CREDIT MANAGEMENT exercising my right to privacy & to Cease all communication directly or indirectly through any mediums & pursuant to Financial Privacy Rule/Gramm Leach Bliley Act, section 6802 to Cease & Desist the sharing unauthorized possession of my non-public information within thirty days.

MIDLAND CREDIT MGMT has not produced competent evidence of my authorized written consent to be in possession of & the sharing of my non-public information within thirty days. 
I obtained updated credit reports from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX MIDLAND CREDIT MGMT has continued communication through the above stated mediums & maintains unauthorized possession of my non-public information without my consent.

In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I hereby request that you investigate and remove these items from my credit report. It is my understanding that you are obligated to verify these items with the creditor responsible for reporting them. Please eliminate any information that can not be verified by the creditor. I am aware that under 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681i ( a ), you are required to complete this investigation within 30 days of receiving this letter.

Please send an updated copy of my credit report to the address provided above. As stipulated by the act, there should be no charge for this updated report. Additionally, I kindly ask that you notify any parties who have accessed my credit report in the past six months regarding the corrections made.

Thank you for your attention and assistance in resolving this matter.

.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

As a victim of this breach, I am entitled to protections under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and other consumer protection laws. The fraudulent accounts listed below were opened without my knowledge or consent and must be permanently removed and blocked from my report. 

The following accounts must be removed immediately : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX data breach, which I obtained from the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX website. Additionally, I have included documentation showing that XXXX has already investigated and removed the fraudulent accounts and inquiries from my credit report. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
RE Account Numbers XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting my nonpublic and personal information without my written consent. Please show me the proof you sent me giving me options on how I could opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and proof showing you gave me the option to not disclose my transaction history each month with a third party. 
The law states a consumer must give written consent to opt out of sharing their nonpublic information to the financial institution. I did this and you stated I did not have that right to opt out. It is a violation to report my transactions or experiences between you and I with a third party or consumer reporting agency without my written consent. It is the policy stated by Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers to insure the security and confidentiality of their customer records and information. This includes protecting against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information which could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to any customer. 

I the consumer should have been given the opportunity, before such information was to be reported which gives me the option to direct you that such information should not be reported. I also should have been explained how I could exercise that nondisclosure option, which I was never advised. I have written multiple times, and you have continued to ignore my written request. 

Your failure to comply with the law and my written request has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Again, I am requesting to opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and for you to remove all my transaction history from all nonaffiliated third parties such as Experian, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX immediately. Otherwise, I will pursue legal actions for every month my nonpublic information has been reported which could be a fine of {$1000.00} per violation. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX, BENEFICIARY Without Recourse, All Rights Reserved

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I looked at my Experian credit report on XX/XX/year> and noticed some things are incomplete and not accurate. And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ).

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In generallf, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Experian, I am writing to formally dispute several inquiries listed on my credit report that occurred as a result of my recent car dealership application. I understand that one inquiry is necessary to process my credit application ; however, multiple inquiries from various lenders were made within a short period, which I did not authorize. 

The inquiries in question occurred on XX/XX/year> and were initiated by several car dealerships in connection with the auto loan application process. These inquiries include the following lenders or financial institutions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXONSUMER PORTFOLIO I kindly request that you investigate these inquiries, as I believe they were not properly authorized under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Please remove any duplicate or unauthorized inquiries from my credit report. 

I have enclosed a copy of my credit report highlighting the disputed inquiries for your reference. I also included a copy of my identification to verify my identity. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter, and I look forward to your prompt response. If you need any further information, please contact me.

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern : When reviewing my credit report, I found several accounts listed in my name that do not belong to me. According to the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act 611 ( a ) [ 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ], these disputed items must be investigated or deleted from my credit record within 30 days. The items I am disputing must be removed from my credit report as the mere reporting of items prior to debt validation constitutes collection activity. I have contacted the Federal Trade Commission and filed a police report. I am demanding that you remove all inaccurate accounts from my credit profile in the next five ( 5 ) days or I will have no other recourse but to file an injunction against your agency under 617a1 which makes you financially liable for each inaccurate account. Also, under 616 Section A liability for willful non-compliance, your agency has yet to respond to my questions and statements of the Law.

AFFIDAVITS OF LAW 1. Are you the original creditor?

2. Have you given the debtor the opportunity to review the original contract?

3. Have you validated the home address for the debtor?

4. Have you complied with all FRCA, FDCP and FDCPA laws?

5. Have you reported to the consumer who has reviewed the original contract information with his/her original signature?

6. Have you provided the names of all creditors that have provided the names and addresses of the person who has reviewed consumer relations? 

Accounts : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX If the above has not been completed, please Delete these accounts from my credit report and stop all contact with me. Under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 U.S.C. Section 805., you are hereby notified to CEASE AND DESIST all further communication with me regarding the referenced debt. Failure to abide by this law will result in a complaint being filed against you with the Federal Trade Commission, the Attorney General of both your state and mine, and also your company management. I also have the right to file suit against you for any future violations of this law.

I have filed an FTC Report and attached a copy of my Ohio Drivers License and Social Card to verify my Identity.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
RE Account Numbers- XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX, T

his letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting my nonpublic and personal information without my written consent. Please show me the proof you sent me giving me options on how I could opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and proof showing you gave me the option to not disclose my transaction history each month with a third party. The law states a consumer must give written consent to opt out of sharing their nonpublic information to the financial institution. I did this and you stated I did not have that right to opt out. It is a violation to report my transactions or experiences between you and I with a third party or consumer reporting agency without my written consent. It is the policy stated by Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers to insure the security and confidentiality of their customer records and information. This includes protecting against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information which could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to any customer. I the consumer should have been given the opportunity, before such information was to be reported which gives me the option to direct you that such information should not be reported. I also should have been explained how I could exercise that nondisclosure option, which I was never advised. I have written multiple times, and you have continued to ignore my written request. Your failure to comply with the law and my written request has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Again, I am requesting to opt out of sharing my nonpublic information and for you to remove all my transaction history from all nonaffiliated third parties such as Experian immediately. Otherwise, I will pursue legal actions for every month my nonpublic information has been reported which could be a fine of {$1000.00} per violation. Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX, BENEFICIARY Without Recourse, All Rights Reserved

This fraudulent, inaccurate, and false information consists of a personal credit card account opened at XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, under the account number ( XXXX ), and a personal credit card account opened at XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, under the account number ( XXXX ). These accounts have resulted in several fraudulent hard inquiries and fraudulent collections appearing on my consumer FICO credit report. I've attached a list of the hard inquiries in question as well as a copy of the consumer FICO credit report maintained by you, which shows the aforementioned fraudulent items. I do not recognize the aforementioned accounts or hard inquiries as reported. The aforementioned accounts and hard inquiries appearing on my consumer credit report maintained by you were not opened, made, or initiated by me. All of the aforementioned accounts and hard inquiries are the result of identity theft and fraud. I have attached a copy of FTC Identity Theft Criminal Complaint # XXXX as proof from the US Federal Trade Commission that all of the aforementioned consumer credit accounts and hard inquiries are the result of identity theft and fraud.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir or Madam : I am a victim of identity theft. I recently learned that my personal information was used to open an account at XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX,, I did not open or authorize this account, and I therefore request that it be closed immediately. I also request that they absolve me of all charges on the account, and that you take all appropriate steps to remove information about this account from my credit files. The identity thef also acquired multiple inquires without my knowledge at XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Enclosed is a copy of my Identity Theft Report supporting my position, and a copy of my credit report showing the fraudulent items related to your company that are the result of identity theft. Also enclosed is a copy of the FTC Notice to Furnishers of Information, which details your responsibilities as an information furnisher to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ). As a furnisher, upon receipt of a consumers written request that encloses an Identity Theft Report, you are required to cease furnishing the information resulting from identity theft to any CRA. 
The Notice also specifies your responsibilities when you receive notice from a CRA, under section 605B of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, that information you provided to the CRA may be the result of identity theft. Those responsibilities include ceasing to provide the inaccurate information to any CRAs and ensuring that you do not attempt to sell or transfer the fraudulent debts to another party for collection. 
Please investigate this matter, close the account and absolve me of all charges, take the steps required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and send me a letter explaining your findings and actions. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Account applications made on paper, online, or by telephone Account statements or invoices Records of payment or charge slips Delivery addresses associated with the account Records of phone numbers used to activate or access the account Signatures on applications and accounts Investigators report Please send me a letter explaining what you have done to Inform XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX that the debt is the result of identity theft Stop collection proceedings against me Stop reporting information about the debt to credit reporting companies Provide me with the records I request Thank you for your cooperation. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX furnishers of consumer reports must comply with all applicable regulations, including regulations promulgated after this notice was rst prescribed in 2004. Information about applicable regulations currently in e ect can be found at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau 's website, consumer nance.gov/learnmore. 
NOTICE TO FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION : OBLIGATIONS OF FURNISHERS UNDER THE FCRA The federal Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681-1681y, imposes responsibilities on all persons who furnish information to consumer reporting agencies ( CRAs ). These responsibilities are found in Section 623 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2. State law may impose additional requirements on furnishers. All furnishers of information to CRAs should become familiar with the applicable laws and may want to consult with their counsel to ensure that they are in compliance. The text of the FCRA is set forth in full at the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection 's website at consumer nance.gov/learnmore. A list of the sections of the FCRA cross-referenced to the U.S. Code is at the end of this document.

Section 623 imposes the following duties : Accuracy Guidelines The banking and credit union regulators and the CFPB will promulgate guidelines and regulations dealing with the accuracy of information provided to CRAs by furnishers. The regulations and guidelines issued by the CFPB will be available at consumer nance.gov/learnmore when they are issued. Section 623 ( e ). 
General Prohibition on Reporting Inaccurate Information The FCRA prohibits information furnishers from providing information to a CRA that they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. However, the furnisher is not subject to this general prohibition if it clearly and conspicuously speci es an address to which consumers may write to notify the furnisher that certain information is inaccurate. Sections 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) and ( a ) ( 1 ) ( C ).

Duty to Correct and Update Information If at any time a person who regularly and in the ordinary course of business furnishes information to one or more CRAs determines that the information provided is not complete or accurate, the furnisher must promptly provide complete and accurate information to the CRA. In addition, the furnisher must notify all CRAs that received the information of any corrections, and must thereafter report only the complete and accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 2 ).

Duties After Notice of Dispute from Consumer If a consumer noti es a furnisher, at an address speci ed by the furnisher for such notices, that speci c information is inaccurate, and the information is, in fact, inaccurate, the furnisher must thereafter report the correct information to CRAs. Section 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ).

If a consumer noti es a furnisher that the consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of any information reported by the furnisher, the furnisher may not subsequently report that information to a CRA without providing notice of the dispute. Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ). 
The federal banking and credit union regulators and the CFPB will issue regulations that will identify when an information furnisher must investigate a dispute made directly to the furnisher by a consumer. Once these regulations are issued, furnishers must comply with them and complete an investigation within 30 days ( or 45 days, if the consumer later provides relevant additional information ) unless the dispute is frivolous or irrelevant or comes from a credit repair organization. The CFPB regulations will be available at consumer nance.gov. Section 623 ( a ) ( 8 ).

Duties After Notice of Dispute from Consumer Reporting Agency If a CRA noti es a furnisher that a consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of information provided by the furnisher, the furnisher has a duty to follow certain procedures. The furnisher must : Conduct an investigation and review all relevant information provided by the CRA, including information given to the CRA by the consumer. Sections 623 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( A ) and ( b ) ( 1 ) ( B ). 
Report the results to the CRA that referred the dispute, and, if the investigation establishes that the information was, in fact, incomplete or inaccurate, report the results to all CRAs to which the furnisher provided the information that compile and maintain les on a nationwide basis. Sections 623 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( C ) and ( b ) ( 1 ) ( D ).

Complete the above steps within 30 days from the date the CRA receives the dispute ( or 45 days, if the consumer later provides relevant additional information to the CRA ). Section 623 ( b ) ( 2 ).

Promptly modify or delete the information, or block its reporting. Section 623 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( E ). 
Duty to Report Voluntary Closing of Credit Accounts If a consumer voluntarily closes a credit account, any person who regularly and in the ordinary course of business furnishes information to one or more CRAs must report this fact when it provides information to CRAs for the time period in which the account was closed. Section 623 ( a ) ( 4 ). 
Duty to Report Dates of Delinquencies If a furnisher reports information concerning a delinquent account placed for collection, charged to pro t or loss, or subject to any similar action, the furnisher must, within 90 days after reporting the information, provide the CRA with the month and the year of the commencement of the delinquency that immediately preceded the action, so that the agency will know how long to keep the information in the consumer 's le. Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ).

Any person, such as a debt collector, that has acquired or is responsible for collecting delinquent accounts and that reports information to CRAs may comply with the requirements of Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( until there is a consumer dispute ) by reporting the same delinquency date previously reported by the creditor. If the creditor did not report this date, they may comply with the FCRA by establishing reasonable procedures to obtain and report delinquency dates, or, if a delinquency date can not be reasonably obtained, by following reasonable procedures to ensure that the date reported precedes the date when the account was placed for collection, charged to pro t or loss, or subjected to any similar action. Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ).

Duties of Financial Institutions When Reporting Negative Information Financial institutions that furnish information to nationwide consumer reporting agencies, as de ned in Section 603 ( p ), must notify consumers in writing if they may furnish or have furnished negative information to a CRA. Section 623 ( a ) ( 7 ). The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has prescribed m
odel disclosures, 12 CFR Part 1022, App. B.

Duties When Furnishing Medical Information A furnisher whose primary business is providing medical services, products, or devices ( and such furnisher 's agents or assignees ) is a medical information furnisher for the purposes of the FCRA and must notify all CRAs to which it reports of this fact. Section 623 ( a ) ( 9 ). This notice will enable CRAs to comply with their duties under Section 604 ( g ) when reporting medical information. 
Duties when ID Theft Occurs All furnishers must have in place reasonable procedures to respond to noti cations from CRAs that information furnished is the result of identity theft, and to prevent refurnishing the information in the future. A furnisher may not furnish information that a consumer has identi ed as resulting from identity theft unless the furnisher subsequently knows or is informed by the consumer that the information is correct. Section 623 ( a ) ( 6 ). If a furnisher learns that it has furnished inaccurate information due to identity theft, it must notify each consumer reporting agency of the correct information and must thereafter report only complete and accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 2 ). When any furnisher of information is noti ed pursuant to the procedures set forth in Section 605B that a debt has resulted from identity theft, the furnisher may not sell, transfer, or place for collection the debt except in certain limited circumstances. Section 615 ( f ). 
The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau website, consumer nance.gov/learnmore, has more information about the FCRA. Citations for FCRA sections in the U.S. Code, 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. : Section 603 Section 604 Section 605 Section 605A Section 605B Section 606 Section 607 Section 608 Section 609 Section 610 Section 611 Section 612 Section 613 Section 614 15 U.S.C. 1681 15 U.S.C. 1681a 15 U.S.C. 1681b 15 U.S.C. 1681c 15 U.S.C. 1681c-1 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 15 U.S.C. 1681d 15 U.S.C. 1681e 15 U.S.C. 1681f 15 U.S.C. 1681g 15 U.S.C. 1681h 15 U.S.C. 1681i 15 U.S.C. 1681j 15 U.S.C. 1681k 15 U.S.C. 1681l Section 615 Section 616 Section 617 Section 618 Section 619 Section 620 Section 621 Section 622 Section 623 Section 624 Section 625 Section 626 Section 627 Section 628 Section 629 15 U.S.C. 1681m 15 U.S.C. 1681n 15 U.S.C. 1681o 15 U.S.C. 1681p 15 U.S.C. 1681q 15 U.S.C. 1681r 15 U.S.C. 1681s 15 U.S.C. 1681s-1 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 15 U.S.C. 1681t 15 U.S.C. 1681u 15 U.S.C. 1681v 15 U.S.C. 1681w 15 U.S.C. 1681x 15 U.S.C. 1681y

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX GA, XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Last 4 SSN : XXXX TODAYS DATE : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX NOTICE OF PENDING LITIGATION SEEKING RELIEF AND MONETARY COMPENSATION UNDER FCRA 15 U.S. Code 1681n Civil liability for willful noncompliance and 15 U.S. Code 1681o Civil liability for negligent noncompliance and 15 U.S. Code 1692k civil liability.

Please accept this final written OFFER OF SETTLEMENT BEFORE LITIGATION as my attempt to amicably resolve your continued violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act regarding your refusal to delete INACCURATE, Unverifiable and Invalidated information from my consumer file. I intend to pursue litigation in accordance with the FCRA to seek relief and recover all monetary damages that I may be entitled to under Section 616 and Section 617 if the INACCURATE, Unverifiable and Invalidated items listed below are not deleted immediately. A copy of this letter as well as INACCURATE ERRONEOUS ITEMS sent to you previously will also become part of a formal complaint to the Federal Trade Commission and shall be used as evidence in pending litigation provided you fail to comply with this offer of settlement. 
YOU ARE IN DIRECT VIOLATION OF THE FCRA, the unverified items listed below still remain on my credit report in violation of Federal Law. You are required under the FCRA to have a copy of the original creditors documentation on file to verify that this information is mine and is correct. In the results of your investigations, you stated in writing that you verified that these items are being reported correctly Who verified these accounts? You have NOT provided me a copy of ANY original documentation ( a consumer contract with my signature on it ) as required under Section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) & Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). Furthermore, you have failed to provide the method of verification as required under Section 611 ( a ) ( 7 ). Please be advised that under Section 611 ( 5 ) ( A ) of the FCRA you are required to ... promptly DELETE all information which can not be verified.

Its very obvious that your agency doesnt know what the FCRA is, because from the looks of my credit report and all the errors I see, heres my breakdown : 1.The Fair Credit Reporting Act is the primary federal law that governs the collection and reporting of credit information about consumers. Its rules cover how a consumer 's credit information is obtained, how long it is kept, and how it is shared with othersincluding consumers themselves.

2. What is a FCRA violation?

Creditors give reporting agencies inaccurate financial information about you. Reporting agencies mixing up one person 's information with another 's because of similar ( or same ) last name or social security number. Agencies fail to follow guidelines for handling disputes.

3. My rights under the fair credit reporting act : Verify the accuracy of my report when it is required for employment purposes.

Receive notification if information in my file has been used against me in applying for credit or other transactions.

Disputeand have the bureaus correct and deleteinformation in my report that is incomplete, inaccurate, and unverifiable.

Remove outdated, negative information ( after seven years in most cases, 10 in the case of bankruptcy ).

I demand these items be deleted immediately. I entered the items and the outcome I desire below because you are in violation and these items are not 100 % accurate.

They are either INACCURATE, Unverifiable and Invalidated. I recently applied for extended credit and was denied I am in distress because of your mistakes.

The law is very clear as to the Civil liability and the remedy available to me ( Section 616 & 617 ) if you fail to comply with Federal Law. I am a litigious consumer and fully intend on pursuing litigation in this matter to enforce my rights under the FCRA.

1. Under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) this account in violation not reporting 100 % accurate. 

XXXX BANK Account Number : XXXX Your improper procedures are highly damaging to my XXXXredit score. Please immediately DELETE VIOLATION OF 15 U.S. Code 1681n - Civil liability for willful noncompliance ( a ) In general Any person who willfully fails to comply with any requirement imposed under this subchapter with respect to any consumer is liable to that consumer in an amount equal to the sum of ( 1 ) ( A ) any actual damages sustained by the consumer as a result of the failure or damages of not less than {$100.00} and not more than {$1000.00} ; or ( B ) in the case of liability of a natural person for obtaining a consumer report under false pretenses or knowingly without a permissible purpose, actual damages sustained by the consumer as a result of the failure or {$1000.00}, whichever is greater ; ( 2 ) such amount of punitive damages as the court may allow ; and ( 3 ) in the case of any successful action to enforce any liability under this section, the costs of the action together with reasonable attorneys fees as determined by the court.

( b ) Civil liability for knowing noncompliance Any person who obtains a consumer report from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses or knowingly without a permissible purpose shall be liable to the consumer reporting agency for actual damages sustained by the consumer reporting agency or {$1000.00}, whichever is greater.

Be advised that the description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information is hereby requested as well, to be provided within ( 5 ) days of the completion of your re-investigation and I am keeping a careful record of your actions, including your Method of Verification. Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint and Cease & Desist Notice Regarding Reporting of Late Payments Dear CFPB, I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding Experian 's continued violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) by refusing to cease and desist from disclosing my nonpublic personal information, specifically late payments on Account # XXXX with XXXX XXXX , to non-affiliated third parties such as XXXX, XXXX, and Experian. 
Despite my previous attempts to resolve this issue, Experian has persisted in sharing this information, which I consider to be a clear breach of federal privacy laws. I am requesting your assistance in addressing this ongoing issue and protecting my consumer rights. 
Cease & Desist Notice This letter serves as a formal Cease & Desist Notice to Experian. I demand that Experian immediately stop reporting my late payments and any nonpublic personal information to third parties. Should this practice continue, I intend to pursue litigation under the FCRA and FDCPA to recover any monetary damages I may be entitled to under the law. 
Fair Credit Reporting Act Violation Experian 's continued reporting of late payments violates my rights under the FCRA, as it constitutes communication of nonpublic personal information. According to 15 USC 1692a ( 2 ), the term communication includes the conveying of information regarding a debt, either directly or indirectly, through any medium. By furnishing late payments to third-party credit reporting agencies, Experian is in direct violation of this provision. 
Additionally, 15 USC 6802 ( b ) prohibits financial institutions from disclosing nonpublic personal information to non-affiliated third parties without the explicit consent of the consumer. Experian has failed to provide any opportunity for me to opt out of this information sharing, which is also a violation of 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( B ). 
Violation of Consumer Rights Experian 's actions infringe upon my consumer and privacy rights. Not only have they shared my nonpublic personal information without my consent, but they have also failed to provide any clear and conspicuous options for opting out of such disclosures. This is in direct violation of 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( C ), which requires an explanation of how a consumer can exercise their right to prevent nonpublic personal information from being disclosed. 
To date, I have not been provided with any opt-out options, forms, notices, or clauses as required by law, either in the original agreement or on Experians website. If Experian asserts that these options were provided, I request that they furnish the original agreement demonstrating the provision of such options, as well as my ability to opt out. 
Request for CFPB Action I am asking the CFPB to take the following actions : Investigate Experian 's failure to comply with the FCRA and federal privacy laws regarding the disclosure of nonpublic personal information. 
Enforce Experians immediate cessation of reporting my late payments to non-affiliated third parties. 
Require Experian to provide an opt-out option for consumers in accordance with federal law and their privacy policy.
